title: New hopes of ceasefire deal as calls to end Israel-Palestinian conflict intensify
body: New hopes of ceasefire deal as calls to end Israel-Palestinian conflict intensifyBy Hadas Gold, Ibrahim Dahman, Hande Atay Alam, and Andrew Carey, CNNUpdated 4:43 PM ET, Thu May 20, 2021 JUST WATCHEDAn Israeli-Palestinian ceasefire could come. Peace may prove elusiveReplayMore Videos ...MUST WATCH (16 Videos)An Israeli-Palestinian ceasefire could come. Peace may prove elusiveChicago mayor only granting interviews to people of colorVoters react to GOP lawmaker's apparent hypocrisy on Capitol riot'Holy cow': See Rep. Ryan's stunned reaction to House voteNY AG has been looking into taxes of Trump Organization CFO for monthsMan who pointed gun at protesters outside his home launches Senate run'There is this bloodthirstiness going on in our party': GOP Arizona election officialJoe Biden singles out Russia and China in commencement addressMcConnell: I made my views about January 6 very clearHear what Republicans are saying about Kevin McCarthy's move'Just disappeared': Veteran combat pilot describes UFO sightingDemocratic House chair calls McCarthy 'weak and cowardly'Lemon: Just another chapter in the saga of GOP hypocrisyTrump orgnaization New York attorney general introduces 'criminal capacity' to Trump probeNew York Gov. Cuomo to receive over $5 million from book deal'Complete abdication': Borger slams McCarthy's announcementJerusalem and Gaza City (CNN)Cautious optimism was growing that a ceasefire between Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza could soon put a halt to days of bloody conflict, but fresh airstrikes and rocket fire Thursday signaled that the violence wasn't over yet.Hamas officials told CNN Wednesday that a halt to the clashes could be "imminent, possibly within 24 hours," as the White House and Europe dialed up pressure on both sides to end the fighting. Israel, however, has not commented on the possibility of a ceasefire deal.US President Joe Biden has ramped up pressure on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to end the fighting with Hamas, giving the Israeli leader a deadline in a call on Wednesday for "a significant de-escalation today on the path to a ceasefire."German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas, right, listens to his Israeli counterpart, Gabi Ashkenazi, center, during a visit Thursday to a building in the Israeli city of Petah Tikva that was hit by rocket fire.European leaders were also stepping up their push to put an end to the turmoil. German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas flew to Israel on Thursday for talks with senior Israeli and Palestinian officials, backing international efforts for a ceasefire and calling for violence to end as soon as possible, though his remarks that "Israel must defend itself against Hamas' rocket terror" prompted a rebuke from the Palestinian militant group. Read MoreGerman Chancellor Angela Merkel made similar remarks in a phone call with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas, with both supporting a ceasefire, according to her spokesman Steffen Seibert."The Chancellor emphasized Israel's right of self-defense against the missile strikes form the Gaza-Strip," he said. France has drafted a UN Security Council resolution seeking a cessation in hostilities and humanitarian access to Gaza, but it has been blocked by the United States, which says it could undermine the Biden administration's efforts to de-escalate. The diplomatic push comes amid mounting concerns over the worsening humanitarian situation in Gaza, where 230 people, including more than 60 children, have been killed in Israeli airstrikes, according to the Hamas-run health ministry there.At least 12 people in Israel, including two children, have been killed by Palestinian militant fire from Gaza during the current round of violence.Airstrikes turned Gaza's schools into shelters. Officials fear Covid-19 may turn them into super-spreader centersThe aid group Doctors Without Borders (MSF) says its staff were being denied permission to cross from Israel into Gaza.Ely Sok, MSF Head of Mission in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, said that "humanitarian needs are mounting, with more than 1,400 people injured and tens of thousands of people displaced."Sok added in a statement that the health system in Gaza was "out of key materials to treat the injured such as blood bags.""We still don't know when our team will be able to cross into Gaza to join our colleagues who are already there. The crossing points need to be reopened immediately and safe passage must be facilitated for humanitarian staff and supplies to avert a greater catastrophe," he said.Israel stopped shipments entering Gaza after the Erez crossing was attacked with mortars on Tuesday. Those attacks were claimed by the military wing of Islamic Jihad.'Even wars have rules,' says UN chiefUN Secretary General Antonio Guterres added his voice to calls for an immediate ceasefire in a impassioned speech in New York."If there is a hell on Earth, it is the lives of children in Gaza today," he said, according to a transcript of his remarks. He said he intended to launch a full humanitarian appeal for funding for the people of Gaza and was working to free up emergency funds."Access for humanitarian goods is paramount. Attacks by militant groups on areas surrounding crossing points are unacceptable," he said."Even wars have rules. First and foremost, civilians must be protected." Relatives of 11-year-old Deema Asaliyeh, who was killed in an Israeli strike, mourn during her funeral ceremony at Jabalia refugee camp in Beit Lahia, Gaza on Thursday. Israel on Thursday saw its longest lull in rocket fire from Gaza -- more than eight hours -- since the conflict broke out on May 10. But by Thursday morning, sirens were sounding again in southern Israel, warning of an incoming barrage of rockets.Meanwhile, Israeli warplanes continued to pound targets in Gaza overnight. Speaking after visiting an Israel Defense Forces command center on Wednesday, Netanyahu said he was "determined to continue this operation until its objective is achieved: to restore quiet and security to you, citizens of Israel."Netanyahu has not clarified whether Israel would support a ceasefire, nor has he commented on Biden's calls for one. In a tweet after his conversation with Biden on Wednesday, he said: "I especially appreciate the support of our friend @POTUS Joe Biden, for the State of Israel's right to self-defense."Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu briefs ambassadors to Israel at the Hakirya military base in Tel Aviv on Wedneday.Biden has grown increasingly eager for the fighting to end, according to officials, but has been wary of publicly applying pressure on Netanyahu, believing the tactic would backfire. But Netanyahu's comments that he plans to continue the operation in Gaza until Hamas targets are taken out have strained US patience, according to officials. Biden made clear to Netanyahu on the call that international pressure would increase if the military campaign continues.Still, Hamas officials tell CNN that ceasefire agreement will most likely be reached within days. A Hamas leader on Wednesday said there was a "positive atmosphere" around the talks to reach an agreement with Israel, "thanks to the support of our Egyptian and Qatari brothers," who proposed different solutions. It was near the site where a previous rocket hit.Hide Caption 8 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemPalestinian mourners carry the body of Obaida Jawabreh, who was killed amid clashes with Israeli forces, during his funeral in the West Bank refugee camp of Al-Arrub on May 18.Hide Caption 9 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemAn Israeli artillery unit fires toward Gaza on May 18.Hide Caption 10 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemPalestinian firefighters douse a fire at the Foamco mattress factory after an Israeli airstrike east of Jabalia, Gaza, on Monday, May 17.Hide Caption 11 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemA woman reacts inside her kitchen on May 17 after a rocket from Gaza hit her apartment building in Ashdod, Israel.Hide Caption 12 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemIsraeli soldiers take cover near the Gaza border as a siren warns them about incoming rockets on May 17.Hide Caption 13 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemChildren salvage toys from their home at Gaza City's Al-Jawhara Tower, which was heavily damaged in Israeli airstrikes.Hide Caption 14 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemPalestinian rescuers pull a survivor from the rubble of a building that was destroyed by an Israeli airstrike in Gaza City on Sunday, May 16.Hide Caption 15 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemThis photo shows the scene of an alleged car ramming in the East Jerusalem neighborhood of Sheikh Jarrah on May 16. Six were injured; the driver was shot and killed. The baby was pulled alive from a building destroyed by an Israeli airstrike, which killed 10 members of the child's family.Hide Caption 20 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in passenger rolls his luggage at the nearly deserted Ben Gurion airport in Lod, Israel, on May 13. Global airlines were canceling flights to Israel as clashes intensified between the country's military and Palestinian militants.Hide Caption 35 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in The boy was killed during fire between Israel and Gaza.Hide Caption 47 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemAn Israeli soldier checks a damaged apartment building in Ashkelon on May 11.Hide Caption 48 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemFlames and smoke rise from buildings in southern Gaza during Israeli airstrikes on May 11.Hide Caption 49 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemIsraeli rescue teams help residents of an Ashkelon neighborhood on May 11.Hide Caption 50 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemPalestinians clash with Israeli security forces at the Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem's Old City on May 10.Hide Caption 51 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemIsraelis take part in the annual Jerusalem Day march on May 10, marking the reunification of Jerusalem after Israel captured the eastern part of the city from Jordan in the 1967 Six-Day War.Hide Caption 52 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemPalestinians are seen at the Aqsa Mosque compound during confrontations with Israeli police on May 10. Hide Caption 53 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemIsraeli police detain a Palestinian during clashes at the Aqsa Mosque on May 10.Hide Caption 54 of 55 Photos: Violence erupts after clashes in JerusalemA Palestinian man runs from tear gas during clashes with Israeli security forces at the Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem's Old City on May 10.Hide Caption 55 of 55Hamas said Israeli warplanes had carried out 1,810 airstrikes on Gaza as of Wednesday, inflicting more than $323 million of damage and destroying at least 1,335 homes. Some 66 schools and primary healthcare clinics have also been damaged; 184 residential towers and office buildings have been razed to the ground; and 33 media institutions have been totally destroyed, according to the Hamas-run ministry of informationA Palestinian man walks past the destroyed Al-Shuruq building in Gaza City on Thursday.Some 72,000 Palestinians in Gaza have also been displaced by Israeli strikes as a result of the UNICEF said Wednesday in a statement, half of which are children. Of those 72,000, UNICEF said, more than 52,000 are "reportedly now sheltering in 48 schools across the Gaza Strip." According to the UN Children's Emergency Fund, one in three children in Gaza was in need of psychological support prior to the recent escalation in the conflict. The number of children with symptoms of psychosocial distress is now expected to have increased. The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA) has launched a $38 million "flash appeal" in aid of what they have described as "the most urgent humanitarian needs" in Gaza and the West Bank.CNN's Eliza Mackintosh, Richard Allen Greene, Kevin Liptak, and Kareem El Damanhoury contributed to this report.An Israeli-Palestinian ceasefire could come.
